awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Touch and Kill: A New Mechanism for Engineered Nanomaterials to Fight Bacteria
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria resistance to antibiotic drugs is a major health challenge to the United States affecting the lives of many people each year. Since bacteria develop resistance to drugs and chemicals over time, it is paramount to the health and well being of our society to find new solutions to effectively kill such bacteria. Nanomaterials that have very few layers of atoms offer exciting new properties to fight against bacteria. This research project aims to understand how atomically-thin nanomaterials interact with bacteria. If this research is successful, it facilitates the design of new antibacterial agents to kill drug-resistant bacteria. This research also has the potential to prevent the development of antibiotic resistance in bacteria. The principal investigators will recruit and mentor female and underrepresented students during the course of this research. In addition, the research findings will be showcased and discussed in relevant undergraduate and graduate classes to further stimulate a new generation of students with the fundamental knowledge to engage in this field. To increase public awareness, the principal investigators will disseminate the new results of this project through social media, press coverage, and news releases. 


Among bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria pose a significant threat to the well being of humanity killing many people each year. Through biochemical evolution, such bacteria usually develop new defensive mechanisms to survive the effects of chemical-based antibiotic drugs. As such, physical-based methods to kill bacteria enable new frontiers to suppress the bacteria resistance. Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials depending on their chemistry and surface properties provide new means to fight bacteria. The goal of this project is to investigate how 2D nanomaterials interact with bacteria. This project will study the interaction of bacteria with certain 2D nanomaterials by direct imaging of hydrated bacteria at high resolutions. It is expected that the high surface reactivity of 2D nanomaterials lead to degradation of bacteria membrane upon contact and eliminate the creation of superbugs by suppressing the capability of bacteria to develop resistance. For broader impacts, the principal investigators will involve students at both undergraduate and graduate levels in training and education on the state-of-the art microscopy techniques for health sciences. Scientific visits and hands-on experience on the lab activities will be showcased for minority and underrepresented students. The finding of this research will be incorporated in a bioengineering graduate course that has been developed for senior undergraduate and graduate students. The principal investigators are committed to recruit female/minority students for undergraduate education through well-established outreach programs at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

por.por_cntn:
The evolving antimicrobial resistance levels for pathogenic bacteria have been a compelling global challenge.  Conventional antibiotics typically act by preventing the upkeep of the cell wall, interfering with the bacterial metabolism, or by inhibiting the synthesis of nucleic acids or proteins. Antibiotics may also depolarize the cell membrane, allowing ion influx. This change in ion concentration can kill bacteria. Antibiotic resistance occurs through limiting uptake of the antibiotic, removal of the antibiotic from within the bacteria, inactivation of the antibiotic through chemical modification or hydrolysis, or modification of the antibiotic's target. To counteract these mutating abilities of bacteria, herein for the first time our research showed the antibacterial interaction of exfoliated non-irradiated phosphorene against the gram-negative Escherichia Coli (E. Coli) bacteria with the help of the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) - ultramicrotomy technique. We have evaluated the various antibacterial physical membrane damage mechanisms. Conclusively, bacteria killing mechanism of exfoliated few-layer black phosphorus (BP), phosphorene, without any irradiation can be attributed to mainly physical damage caused by puckered structure and lateral size of flexible BP nanosheets. Physical interactions of BP nanosheets can promote membrane damage by sharp edges, increased membrane permeability and cytoplasm detachment by puckered surface morphology, lipid bilayer extraction, and osmotic imbalance. Additionally, BP nanosheets can act as a flexible barrier obstructing the intake of environmental nutrients and can disrupt protein-protein interactions, which affects adversely on bacterial defense mechanisms. Considering as-synthesized BP nanosheets were not irradiated with UV light, we believe reactive oxygen species (ROS) did not play a major role in antibacterial activity. Rather as a contributor oxidized BP nanosheets would have produced phosphoric acid in water, which eventually adversely affects transmembrane pH.

Our research suggests that the phosphorene nanosheets have greater potential to kill continuously evolving AMR species and superbugs such as methicillin resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA), upon physical contact. Future research aspects will be involved with the testing of exfoliated non-irradiated phosphorene nanosheets against superbugs species.

As a result of this award 4 peer reviewed articles and one conference papere were published, 2 talks were presented at conferences, and one invention was disclosed: Drug-free Chemically Stable Non-Irradiated 2D Black Phosphorus with Immediate and Lasting Antimicrobial properties. 

As a result of the broader impacts of this award total of 6 PhD students, 1 postdoc researcher and 3 undergraduate students were trained on various project aspects of material research, antibacterial studies and electron-microscopy techniques of this award. To address the research questions and underlying mechanisms the collaborative efforts were taken among University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) Bioengineering department- In-situ Nanomedicine Laboratory (ISNL) and UIC Mechanical and Industrial Engineering department- NanoEngineering Laboratory by working on this award.
